4.14.text: Jane Austen is loved mainly as a guide to fashionable life in the Regency period,

9.80.text: but her own vision of her task was radically different.

13.14.text: She was an ambitious and stern moralist.

16.56.text: She was acutely conscience of human failings and wanted, through her novels,

20.58.text: to make people less selfish and more reasonable.

24.48.text: More dignified, and sensitive to the needs of others.

28.14.text: Born in 1775, Austen grew up in a small village in Hampshire, where her father was the Anglican rector.

34.94.text: They had high social status, but were not well off.

37.84.text: She did much of her writing at a tiny octagonal table.

41.36.text: She never married, though on a couple of occasions she was tempted.

44.60.text: Mostly, she lived in the country with her sister, Cassandra.

48.06.text: The novel was her chosen weapon in the struggle to reform humanity.

52.54.text: She completed six: Sense and Sensibility, Pride and Prejudice, Mansfield Park, Emma, Northanger Abbey, and Persuasion.

59.40.text: Some of the main things she wants to teach you are:

63.46.text: In Pride and Prejudice, Mr. Darcy and Elizabeth Bennet start off heartily disliking each other

69.02.text: and then gradually realize they're in love.

71.40.text: They make one of the great romantic couples.

74.02.text: But why actually are they right for one another?

76.68.text: Austen in very clear: it's for a reason we tend not to think of very much today.

81.36.text: Each can educate and improve the other.

84.44.text: Darcy starts of feeling superior, because he has more money and higher status.

89.50.text: Then, at a key moment, Elizabeth condemns his arrogance and pride to his face.

93.86.text: It sounds offensive, but later he admits, "Your reproof so well applied, I shall never forget.

99.64.text: "You taught me a lesson, hard indeed at first, but most advantageous.

106.78.text: They suit each other because by her ease and liveliness, his mind might have been softened,

112.22.text: his manners improved, and from his judgment,

114.90.text: information and knowledge of the world, she must have received benefit of greater importance.

120.32.text: In other words, they balance each other out.

123.28.text: We tend to think of love as liking someone for who they are already - total acceptance.

128.38.text: But Austen is saying that the right person has got to be able to help us overcome our failings.

133.48.text: And become more mature, honest, and kind; and we need to do something similar for them.

138.48.text: Darcy and Elizabeth improve one another, and then the novelist lets them get engaged.

144.00.text: The story rewards them because they have developed well.

147.48.text: That's why the novel feels so beautifully constructed, and it illustrates a basic truth:

153.12.text: marriage depends on maturity and education.

161.48.text: Mansfield Park starts when quiet, shy Fanny Price goes to live with her much richer cousins, the Bertrams.

167.40.text: In social terms, the Bertrams are stars, and Fanny is a very minor character indeed.

172.70.text: But Austen judges by a completely different standard.

175.78.text: She exchanges the normal lens through which people are viewed in society,

179.68.text: a lens which magnifies wealth and power, for a moral lens, which magnifies qualities of character.

185.92.text: Certainly, Fanny has no elegant dresses or money and can't speak French,

190.06.text: But by the end of Mansfield Park, she is revealed as the noble one

194.20.text: while the Bertrams, despite their titles and accomplishments, have fallen into moral confusion.

201.74.text: Austen is quite frank about money.

203.58.text: In Pride and Prejudice, she explains that Mr. Bingley has an income of 4000 pounds a year - that's rather a lot -

209.32.text: while Darcy has more than twice that. Rather than feeling it's impolite to discuss money,

214.04.text: Austen thinks it's an eminently suitable topic for highbrow literature.

217.78.text: Because how we handle our finances has a huge effect on our lives.

221.98.text: She takes aim at two big mistakes people make around money.

225.76.text: The first is to get over impressed by it. In Mansfield Park, Julia Bertram gets married to Mr. Rushworth,

232.24.text: the richest character in all of Austen's novels,

234.54.text: but they are miserable together, and their marriage rapidly falls apart.

238.78.text: But equally, Austen is convinced that it's a serious error to get married without enough money.

243.92.text: At one point in Sense and Sensibility, it looks like Elinor Dashwood and Edward Ferrars -

248.50.text: who are otherwise well suited - won't be able to get married.

251.52.text: She writes, "They were neither of them quite enough in love to think that 350 pounds a year would supply them with the comforts of life."

259.52.text: Elinor takes the view that wealth has much to do with happiness.

263.60.text: Though, by wealth, she doesn't mean great luxury, just enough to live carefully in moderate comfort.

270.76.text: Marriage without a reasonable economic basis is just a folly.

274.76.text: Austen is showing us an elusive but crucial attitude.

278.34.text: Money is in some ways extremely important, and in other ways unimportant. We can't just be for it or against it.

288.86.text: In Emma, the heroine - Emma herself - takes Harriett Smith - a pretty girl from the village - under her wing.

294.36.text: She wants to make her an impressive match with a smart vicar.

297.88.text: Swept away by Emma's excessive praise, Harriet turns down an offer of marriage from a farmer

303.14.text: because she thinks now that he's not good enough.

306.18.text: Though in fact, he is good-hearted and quietly prosperous.

309.56.text: Then the vicar turns out to be horrified at Emma's idea and Harriet has her heart broken.

314.82.text: The underlying point is serious, Emma is unwittingly but cruelly snobbish.

320.18.text: She's devoted to the wrong kind of hierarchy.

322.94.text: The farmer is essentially a better person than the vicar,

326.56.text: but social conventions and manners make it easy to ignore this.

331.12.text: Jane Austen is careful to give this fault to Emma, who is in many ways an enchanting character.

336.66.text: In other words, Jane Austen doesn't mock snobbery as the behavior of ghastly and contemptible people.

342.42.text: Instead, she regards the snob with pity, as someone who's in need of instruction, guidance, and reform.

349.00.text: As we all are, in our own way.

351.76.text: Austen might have written sermons; she wrote novels instead.

355.42.text: She doesn't tell us why her sense of priorities is important, instead, she shows us in a story

361.28.text: which will also make us laugh, which can grip us enough that we want to finish supper early to read on.

366.30.text: Upon finishing one of the novels, we're invited to go back into the world and respond to others as she has taught us.

372.80.text: To pick up on, and recoil from greed, arrogance, and pride,

377.12.text: and to be drawn to goodness within ourselves and others.

380.18.text: Sadly, the moral ambition of the novel has largely disappeared in the modern world,

384.86.text: yet it's really the best thing that any novel can do.

387.92.text: The satisfaction we feel when reading Jane Austen is really because she wants the world to be a certain way

393.94.text: and we find that immensely appealing.

396.44.text: It's the secret, largely unrecognized reason why she is such a loved writer.
